[[Sungri 4.10]]
[[Sungri 4.25]]
[[UAZ-69]] |production=1951-1972 (in Romania - until 1975) |model_years= |assembly=[[Nizhny Novgorod|Gorky]], [[Ulyanovsk]] (USSR) |predecessor={{ubl|[[GAZ-67]]|[[Willys MB]]}} |successor=[[UAZ-469]] |class=Light truck |body_style=2-door cargo, 4-door field car |layout=[[F4 layout]] |platform= |related = [[ARO IMS|IMS-57, M59, ARO M461]] |engine=2.1L ''GAZ-69'' [[Inline-four engine|I4]] |transmission=3-speed manual |wheelbase = {{convert|2300|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|3850|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|1750|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|1950|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|1535|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} }} [[File:Gaz-uaz.jpg|thumb|right|GAZ-69A]] The '''GAZ-69''' is a [[four-wheel drive]] light truck, produced by [[GAZ]] (ГАЗ, or ''Gorkovsky Avtomobilnyi Zavod'', Gorky Automobile Factory) between 1953 and 1956 and then by [[UAZ]], in 1956–1972, though all of these vehicles were known as GAZ-69s. Extremely popular in the Soviet Union, it was copied by a number of foreign companies.Thompson, Andy. ''Cars of the Soviet Union'' (Haynes Publishing, Somerset, UK, 2008), p. 70. ==Development and production== The GAZ-69 was created by the team of chief designer Grigoriy Vasserman as a replacement for the [[GAZ-67|GAZ-67B]] that would have lower fuel consumption than its predecessor and use the same {{convert|55|hp|kW PS|lk=on|abbr=on}} {{convert|2.1|L|cid|abbr=on}} inline four and three-speed [[Transmission (mechanics)|transmission]] as the [[GAZ-M20|GAZ-M20 ''Pobeda'']]. The development process started in 1946 and the first prototypes known under the name "Truzhenik" (Toiler) were built in 1947. After extensive on-road testing, the new off-road vehicle went into production on August 25, 1953.{{ru icon}} {{cite web | url=http://www.off-road-drive.ru/archive/32/Geroy_soctruda | title=The history of the development of the GAZ-69| publisher=www.off-road-drive.ru}} Over 600,000 GAZ-69s had been built by the end of production in the USSR in 1972. A similar vehicle based upon the GAZ-69's design was produced by [[ARO]] in Romania until 1975, first as the [[ARO IMS#IMS-57|IMS-57]], then as the [[ARO IMS#M59|IMS M59]], and later modernized as the [[ARO IMS#M461|ARO M461]].''IMS M461'', "Avtolegendy SSSR i Socstran" No. 168, DeAgostini 2015, ISSN 2071-095X {{icon ru}}, p.3-6 GAZ-69s were standard military jeeps of the Eastern Bloc and client states. ==Design== The standard GAZ-69 was able to reach {{convert|56|mph|km/h|abbr=on}},Thompson, p. 176. but its more powered versions, with 2400 cc (derived from the basic 2100 cc) 65 h.p. engines and the same three-speed gearbox, could reach {{convert|100|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. They were known as the GAZ-69M, or GAZ-69AM for the four-door version.Ware, Pat. ''The World Encyclopedia of Military Vehicles'' (Lorenz Books, 2010), p. 177. It featured two fuel tanks, one of {{convert|47|l|usgal impgal|0}} under the floor, one of {{convert|28|l|usgal impgal|0}} beneath the passenger's seat. All civilian models also had to meet [[Soviet Army|Army]] requirements, in case of wartime [[Expropriation|requisitioning]]. (This is also why a hardtop version was not available until 1993)Thompson, p. 176 The basic variant '''GAZ-69''' has a pair of doors and usually has standard canvas top and upper sides; there are two seats in front and two folding benches for three passengers each on sides. The further variant '''GAZ-69A''' (UAZ-69A) has four doors, folding canvas top and two rows of seats. It was used as the basis for the rear-wheel drive van GAZ-19 that was built in 1955 but didn't pass the prototype stage. The off-road van and light truck [[UAZ-452|UAZ-450]] and the newer [[UAZ-469]] also traced their origins to the GAZ-69. ==Military use== The GAZ-69 had been the basic light off-road vehicle of the Soviet Army, replacing [[GAZ-67]]s and [[Willys MB|Willys Jeeps]], before the army adopted the [[UAZ-469]]. It was also used as the basis for the [[3M6 Shmel#History|2P26]] [[tank destroyer]], as well as for the [[GAZ 46]] MAV, a light [[4x4]] [[amphibious vehicle]] inspired by the [[Ford GPA]] 'Seep'. ==Gallery== File:GAZ69-MoT-STL.jpg|A retired GAZ-69 in the [[Museum of Transportation]] in [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri|Mo]], United States File:UAZ-69.jpg|A retired GAZ-69 in the {{Interlanguage link multi|Fort aan den Hoek van Holland|nl}} in [[Hoek van Holland]], [[Netherlands]] File:FUG_2.jpg|A GAZ-69 of the Hungarian Army File:Gaz-uaz-69m-1958-20130502-l.jpg|UAZ-69M, front view File:GAZ-69_Armaturenbrett.jpg|GAZ-69, interior == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.gaz69.org/ GAZ-69 – Everything you want to know about the GAZ-69] * [http://www.mortarinvestments.eu/products/jeeps,-trucks-a-motos-3/gaz-69-63 GAZ-69 on sale at the Mortar Investments website] * [http://www.sovietarmor.com/catalog/armored/gaz_69.html GAZ-69 at the Soviet Armor website] [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Off-road vehicles]] [[Category:GAZ]] [[Category:Military vehicles of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Military light utility vehicles]] [[Category:Military trucks]]
